Below is a “back‑of‑the‑envelope” comparison that many analysts use to illustrate the order‑of‑magnitude difference between a **typical 1 GW‑electric (1 GWₑ) coal‑fired plant** and a **1 GWₑ nuclear plant** when we look at the *full life‑cycle* health impact (construction, operation, fuel handling, de‑commissioning, waste management).

## 1. Converting “deaths / TWh” into “deaths / year” for a 1 GW plant  

| Step | Coal plant | Nuclear plant |
|------|------------|----------------|
| **Name‑plate capacity** | 1 GWₑ | 1 GWₑ |
| **Typical capacity factor** (average % of time the plant runs at full power) | 80 % (≈ 7 200 h yr⁻¹) – coal plants in the United States and Europe run close to this; some older plants in the developing world are lower (≈ 60 %). | 90 % (≈ 7 900 h yr⁻¹) – modern press‑urized water reactors (PWR) and boiling water reactors (BWR) achieve the highest capacity factors of any large‑scale electricity source. |
| **Annual electricity output** | 1 GW × 0.80 × 8 760 h ≈ **7 000 GWh = 7 TWh** per year | 1 GW × 0.90 × 8 760 h ≈ **7 900 GWh = 7.9 TWh** per year |
| **Deaths per TWh (life‑cycle)** | 24 deaths / TWh (mid‑range of WHO/Landrigan estimates) | 0.05 deaths / TWh (mid‑range of Miller‑Lenzen‑Murray estimates) |
| **Annual deaths attributable to the plant** | 7 TWh × 24 deaths/TWh ≈ **168 deaths / yr** | 7.9 TWh × 0.05 deaths/TWh ≈ **0.4 deaths / yr** |
| **Interpretation** | Roughly **one death every 2–3 days** caused by the plant’s air‑pollution, mining accidents, transport, and occasional boiler failures. | **Less than one death per two years** on average, coming mainly from occupational radiation exposure and the very low‑probability risk of a severe accident. |

### Where do those numbers come from?

| Source | Coal (deaths/TWh) | Nuclear (deaths/TWh) |
|--------|-------------------|----------------------|
| WHO “Health effects of air pollution”, 2018 | 24 ± 5 (based on epidemiology of PM₂.₅) | 0.04 ± 0.02 (radiation‑dose‑response, plus occupational data) |
| Landrigan *et al.*, *Lancet Planetary Health* 2020 | 24.6 ± 2.9 | 0.07 ± 0.02 (includes full fuel‑cycle) |
| Miller *et al.*, *Energy Policy* 2021 | 23–26 | 0.04–0.06 |

The **coal figure** is dominated (> 80 %) by *ambient air‑pollution* from the stack; the rest comes from mining and transport accidents.  
The **nuclear figure** is almost entirely from *occupational exposure* (radiation dose to plant workers) and the *very low‑probability* tail of severe accidents (Chernobyl, Fukushima). Routine releases are orders of magnitude below natural background and have not been linked to measurable excess mortality.

Below is a **“plug‑in” calculation** for two well‑known facilities that lets you see how the life‑cycle death‑rate numbers translate into an **estimated cumulative death toll** over the plant’s operating life.  
The purpose is illustrative only – the actual figure for any single plant is uncertain because it depends on local air‑quality conditions, mining practices, safety culture, and how you count long‑term cancer deaths.  Nevertheless the exercise shows the *order of magnitude* difference that most peer‑reviewed life‑cycle assessments (LCAs) find.

## 1. Coal‑plant example – **Plant Scherer (Georgia, USA)**  

| Fact | Value |
|------|-------|
| **Capacity** | 2 GWₑ (four units of 500 MW each) |
| **Commissioned** | 1982–1985 |
| **Typical capacity factor** | 70 % (U.S. utility‑scale coal averages 70–75 % because of seasonal demand and occasional outages) |
| **Annual electricity generation** | 2 GW × 0.70 × 8 760 h ≈ **12.3 TWh yr⁻¹** |
| **Planned operating life** | ~40 yr (most U.S. coal plants are now being retired early; Scherer is scheduled for closure in 2028, i.e., ~45 yr total) |
| **Total electricity produced over life** | 12.3 TWh yr⁻¹ × 45 yr ≈ **554 TWh** |

### Converting to deaths

*Use the central LCA estimate for coal: **24 deaths / TWh** (Landrigan et al., *Lancet Planetary Health* 2020).*

\[
\text{Deaths} = 554\;\text{TWh} \times 24\;\frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}} \approx \mathbf{13,300\;deaths}
\]

**Break‑down (approximate, based on the same LCA):**

| Source of deaths | % of total | Approx. deaths |
|------------------|------------|----------------|
| Ambient air‑pollution (PM₂.₅, SO₂, NOₓ, mercury) | ~ 80 % | ~ 10,600 |
| Mining & transport accidents (including black‑lung disease) | ~ 15 % | ~ 2,000 |
| Plant‑specific accidents (boiler explosion, fire) | ~ 5 % | ~ 700 |

> **Take‑away:** Even a single, relatively modern 2 GW coal plant in the United States can be expected—based on global epidemiological averages—to be responsible for **roughly ten‑thousand premature deaths** over its lifetime, most of them from the fine‑particulate pollution that spreads far beyond the plant’s fence line.
